title: How to Prepare Your Neighborhood for a Major Emergency

steps.headline: Discuss with your neighbors their interest in a disaster preparedness group, and determine who the leader will be.
Conduct your first meeting as a session to air concerns of what might possibly happen in your area.
steps.description: Discuss such things as flooding, wildfires, tornadoes, hurricane, earthquakes and anything else that becomes a topic of concern for you and your neighbors.

steps.headline: Delegate a committee member or group of people to research the topic and what should be done in that circumstance, and task them to come prepared to speak on the topic at the next meeting.
steps.description: Expectations include what individuals can do to prepare ahead of time for a disaster, emergency steps to take when a disaster happens and follow-up recovery steps that should be taken by individuals and the neighborhood as a whole after a disaster. Wildfire preparedness resources primarily directed at US citizens, can be found through FEMA at http://www.ready.gov/wildfires. Your flood preparedness group can start its research at http://www.ready.gov/floods or any other similar website relevant to your location. Begin your tornado preparedness research at http://www.ready.gov/tornadoes.

steps.headline: Consider asking local law enforcement or other emergency response personnel to speak to your group.
steps.description: Because they are typically the first responders, they may be able to offer you insight that research cannot.

steps.headline: Educate families on how disaster preparedness starts at home.
steps.description: Direct your families to the FEMA website's disaster preparedness page at http://www.ready.gov/build-a-kit, and encourage them to create their own kits. By everyone making an effort to secure the needs of their families, group resources are not wasted.

steps.headline: Reassemble your group to discuss what was found in the research, and then disseminate pertinent information to all families in the neighborhood.
steps.description: This could be done electronically via email, on a social media website, or door-to-door using fliers. Whichever method you choose, make sure that every family in the neighborhood receives the information.

steps.headline: Discuss at your meetings the possibility of a communication tree.
steps.description: If danger is imminent, a communication tree can be used to contact one another to give warning.

text: Discuss with your neighbors their interest in a disaster preparedness group, and determine who the leader will be.  Conduct your first meeting as a session to air concerns of what might possibly happen in your area. Discuss such things as flooding, wildfires, tornadoes, hurricane, earthquakes and anything else that becomes a topic of concern for you and your neighbors. Delegate a committee member or group of people to research the topic and what should be done in that circumstance, and task them to come prepared to speak on the topic at the next meeting. Expectations include what individuals can do to prepare ahead of time for a disaster, emergency steps to take when a disaster happens and follow-up recovery steps that should be taken by individuals and the neighborhood as a whole after a disaster. Wildfire preparedness resources primarily directed at US citizens, can be found through FEMA at http://www.ready.gov/wildfires. Your flood preparedness group can start its research at http://www.ready.gov/floods or any other similar website relevant to your location. Begin your tornado preparedness research at http://www.ready.gov/tornadoes. Consider asking local law enforcement or other emergency response personnel to speak to your group. Because they are typically the first responders, they may be able to offer you insight that research cannot. Educate families on how disaster preparedness starts at home. Direct your families to the FEMA website's disaster preparedness page at http://www.ready.gov/build-a-kit, and encourage them to create their own kits. By everyone making an effort to secure the needs of their families, group resources are not wasted. Reassemble your group to discuss what was found in the research, and then disseminate pertinent information to all families in the neighborhood. This could be done electronically via email, on a social media website, or door-to-door using fliers. Whichever method you choose, make sure that every family in the neighborhood receives the information. Discuss at your meetings the possibility of a communication tree. If danger is imminent, a communication tree can be used to contact one another to give warning.
